title: In the Matter of David B. Greene
description: This is an attorney disciplinary matter.
text:
Greene

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of David B. Greene, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26232
Heard October 31, 2006 - Filed December 4, 2006Â  

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
        Henry D. McMaster, Attorney General, and James G. Bogle, Jr., Senior Assistant Attorney General, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: In this attorney disciplinary matter, the full panel adopted the sub-panel report and the recommendation that respondent, David B. Greene, be suspended from the practice of law for nine months, with conditions, and be required to pay the costs of the proceedings. Â We agree with the recommended sanction.
FACTS
In 1998, respondent unwittingly became part of an illegal pyramid scheme disguised as an evangelical ministry, known as HISway International Ministries (â€œHISwayâ€ or â€œHIMâ€).Â  Respondentâ€™s involvement included (1) investing his own money with the ministry; (2) representing Rev. Johnny Cabe and HIM in a federal criminal investigation and in all other legal matters; and (3) acting as escrow agent for HIM.Â  In the capacity of escrow agent, respondent allowed HIM to use his lawyerâ€™s trust account for deposits and disbursements after HIMâ€™s American accounts had all been frozen by the government.
Cabe eventually was convicted of 26 counts of wire fraud and money laundering.[1]Â  Cabeâ€™s convictions were affirmed by the Fourth Circuit in a written opinion, which was submitted as one of Disciplinary Counselâ€™s exhibits.Â  From that opinion, the following facts are excerpted because they effectively explain the pyramid scheme and provide some background to this disciplinary matter:

  Cabe was pastor of a small independent Baptist church in Rock Hill, South Carolina. Â Beginning in January 1998 and continuing through October 1998, Cabe and another minister, Shelton Joel Shirley, solicited individuals to invest money in an investment scheme called â€œhigh yield trading programs.â€ Â They promoted the scheme as a charitable venture affiliated with a religious organization, Hisway International Ministries of London, England.â€¦ Â Cabe and Shirley told potential investors that they had contacts with â€œtradersâ€ who would invest their money in European bank debentures. Â Some solicitations described the investments as charitable â€œgiftsâ€ and the return of investments as â€œre-giftsâ€ and suggested that because of their charitable nature, there would be no tax consequences.
  Cabe portrayed the investment programs as profitable and without risk and claimed that investors typically would double their money within thirty to ninety days of investment.â€¦
  Potential investors were given documents describing the lucrative nature of the scheme and prohibiting them from revealing any information relating to it. Â The documents instructed that if any such disclosure occurred, the investor would forfeit the investment. Â Investors were also required to pay a three percent â€œadministration giftâ€ fee to Cabe on every transaction.
  On January 9, 1998, Cabe began establishing bank accounts in order to aggregate and aid in the transfer of investorsâ€™ funds. Â Upon receiving contributions from investors, Cabe wired the funds to various organizations and individuals for alleged investment. Â The evidence at trial showed that these investments were in fact fictitious and that the money was stolen by the traders. Â Moreover, the evidence established that $679,317 of investorsâ€™ contributions were [sic] diverted to Cabe, Shirley, and their families.
  In the course of their dealings with investors, Cabe and Shirley recruited â€œstewardsâ€ for the scheme. Â After making a contribution to Cabeâ€™s ministry, the stewards were tasked with recruiting other investors for the programs. Â In order to recruit stewards, some of whom were already investors, Cabe provided them with literature detailing the success of the programs. Â In return for recruiting new investors, these stewards expected to receive a portion of the profits from maturing investments.
  In meetings with investors, Cabe categorically stated that none of his prior investments had faced any problems. Â However, beginning in April 1998, Cabe complained to the â€œtradersâ€ that he had not received any return on the investments and was unable to pay any of his contributors. Â He expressed concern that he would not only lose future potential investors, but that he also might be â€œsued for fraud.â€ Â Even with this knowledge, however, Cabe continued to solicit investors with representations that the programs were highly profitable and risk-free.
  Â In July 1998, after certain of the investors demanded payment of the promised return on their investments, Cabe transferred money to some of them. Â Cabe represented that these payments were profits from their investments in the trading programs. Â However, these funds were in reality from the aggregated funds of new investors. Â The evidence presented at trial showed that these payments to investors were made to prove the programs profitable and to encourage further investments.
  Â â€¦
  Eventually Cabe and Shirley were indicted in the court below. Â Shirley pleaded guilty and testified for the government at trial. Â One of the alleged traders, Terence Wingrove, an English art dealer, also testified for the government pursuant to a plea agreement. Â He admitted that he had received several million dollars in investment money from Cabe.

United States v. Cabe, 57 Fed.Appx. 542, 543-44 (4th Cir. 2003) (footnote omitted).Â  
 Respondent was drawn into the scheme through his friend, Dennis Smith, who he had known for 25 years.[2]Â  Smith met Cabe around March 1998; Cabe explained to Smith that HIM planned to â€œspread goodwill internationallyâ€ by raising money through debenture trading.Â  The profits from this international trading would be used for benevolent and religious causes, and the original â€œdonorsâ€ would be â€œre-giftedâ€ or rewarded with substantial returns.Â  More specifically, HIMâ€™s pitch was that if a person made a â€œgiftâ€ to the ministry, that personâ€™s money would increase by 500%; the donor would receive 200% in return, therefore doubling the money, and the other 300% would be used for the ministryâ€™s world wide Christian missionary programs.Â  Smith acted as a steward for HIM and stated he was taken in â€œhook, line and sinker.â€ Â Smith testified that he believed respondentâ€™s involvement was based on respondentâ€™s trust in him.
Respondent gave $50,000.00 to HISway in May 1998.Â  Respondent testified that his initial involvement resulted completely from his reliance on Smithâ€™s verbal representations about HIM.[3] 
The Secret Service began to investigate HIM, and in July 1998, the government froze all of HIMâ€™s bank accounts.Â  Respondent learned of this in late September 1998 at a meeting in his office attended by Smith and Roy Palmer;[4] Cabe also participated in the meeting via telephone from England.Â  Regarding the frozen accounts, it was represented to respondent that it was all â€œa big mistake.â€ Â It was also at this meeting when respondent was asked to legally represent Cabe and HIM in the criminal investigation[5] and to act as escrow agent for HIM by using his law firmâ€™s trust account.[6]Â  
According to respondent, Smith and Palmer presented the idea of using his trust account.Â  Smith and Palmer told respondent that several people were owed â€œre-giftsâ€ of money, but could not be paid because of the frozen accounts, as well as others who â€œwanted to get in onâ€ the trading.Â  Respondent testified that he told Cabe the following:Â  â€œI will let these donors donate money to HISway and Iâ€™ll let you place it in my trust account.Â  We can get some of these other people paid back.â€Â  According to Smith, however, it was specifically suggested to use respondentâ€™s trust account because it was an account that could not be frozen by the government.Â  Smith could not recall who made this suggestion.Â  Respondent denies knowing this was the reason he was asked to use his trust account.
On October 26, 1998, respondentâ€™s legal representation of Cabe and HIM â€œin all matters necessaryâ€ was memorialized in writing with the parties agreeing to a $5,000.00 retainer for respondent.Â  Disciplinary Counsel presented evidence that respondent did not usually do criminal defense work; when questioned about why he took on the case, respondent replied that he believed Cabe was innocent and knew that if necessary, he â€œcould always associate someone.â€
From September 30, 1998 to November 3, 1998, ten deposits were made into respondentâ€™s trust account related to HISway, for a total of $468,280.00.Â  This included a $150,000.00 deposit from attorney John Hagins as well as another $50,000.00 deposit from respondent himself.Â  Approximately 25 payments related to HISway were made from respondentâ€™s trust account between October 1, 1998, and March 24, 1999, for a total of $426,957.50 in disbursements.Â  These payments included $5,000.00 and $3,917.50 to respondent himself for attorney fees related to his representation of Cabe and HIM.Â  The other expenditures were paid to various people and companies, including, for example, Cabeâ€™s Corner Store.[7]Â  Respondent did not independently investigate who the payees were; however, he believed the money belonged to his clients, Cabe and HISway, and therefore he felt obligated to make disbursements as directed by Cabe and Cabeâ€™s designees, Palmer and Smith.
Complainant John Dill explained that Smith told him about HIM, and Dill believed he would double his money within 45 days.Â  Dill made two $50,000.00 investments with HIM - one was made before respondent got involved and one after.Â  The latter investment was wired directly into respondentâ€™s trust account.Â  Dill stated that he felt that his money would be safe in an attorneyâ€™s trust account and that he had a lawyer-client relationship by virtue of the wire transfer and what Smith had told him.Â  Prior to making this second payment, Dill was required to sign a â€œReaffirmation Affidavitâ€ wherein he â€œreaffirmedâ€ that any money given had been an â€œunsolicited donationâ€ without any promises made.Â  
Complainant Ann Barnes also made two payments to HISway -Â Â  $11,000.00 in the summer of 1998, and $25,000.00 in fall of 1998.Â  When Barnes was asked by Palmer for the second payment, Barnes knew the accounts had been frozen.Â  Palmer explained that respondent, an attorney, would be handling all the money, and so Barnes sent her $25,000 payment to respondentâ€™s trust account by cashierâ€™s check.Â  Barnes stated that based on what Palmer had told her, she believed that respondent was representing her interests.Â  Barnes also signed a Reaffirmation Affidavit when she made her second payment.Â  
Attorney Johnny Hagins testified that Palmer introduced him to HISway.Â  Hagins invested $100,000.00 in March 1998, and five months later, he received $150,000.00 back.Â  Hagins became aware that the HISway accounts had been frozen, but at a meeting he was told that the trades had been successful, and the money was being held in a European account.Â  In the fall of 1998, Hagins went to a meeting at respondentâ€™s office with respondent, Cabe and Shirley, and he learned that respondent would be, in Haginsâ€™ words, a â€œgatekeeperâ€ for the money by using his trust account.Â  After HIM associated with respondent, Hagins made two additional payments of $150,000.00 and $35,000.00 at the beginning of October 1998.Â  By January of 1999, Hagins was upset he had not seen the return on his investment.Â  Respondent, Hagins, Palmer, Smith, and Cabe again met in respondentâ€™s office, and Hagins said they told respondent they wanted him â€œto birddog this thing and make sure itâ€™s done right.â€Â  
In March 1999, respondent began attempting to end his legal representation of Cabe and HIM.Â  He eventually withdrew in May 1999.Â  Although he had had several discussions as Cabeâ€™s lawyer with the Secret Service and the Assistant U.S. Attorney, he never made an appearance for Cabe in federal court.Â  Therefore, he unilaterally withdrew as Cabeâ€™s lawyer.Â  
Respondent met with Hagins in March 1999, and told him the money was â€œjust about all gone.â€Â  Respondent also informed Hagins that he had sent out the money as directed by Cabe, Smith, and Palmer.[8] 
After Cabeâ€™s conviction, the federal district court issued an order regarding the distribution of funds that had been seized by the government to victims of the HIM fraud.Â  Respondent himself sought some reimbursement for his losses from the federal court.Â  He asserted in a November 1999 affidavit that his payments were investments; however, because he initially characterized his payments as gifts during a January 1999 interview with the Secret Service, he was disallowed any monetary recovery.Â  United States v. Cabe, 311 F.Supp.2d 501 (2003).
Mitigating Circumstances
Respondent testified that he never believed Cabe was involved in anything illegal and if he had suspected wrongdoing, he would not have represented Cabe.Â  Once it became clear to him that Cabe was unwilling to assist the governmentâ€™s case and there had been an illegal scheme, he began to withdraw as Cabeâ€™s lawyer.Â  In an attempt to explain why he was duped, he told the panel that he believed HIM to be an international ministry governed by a blind trust and the money was going to be used for â€œeleemosynary purposes and Christian endeavors.â€Â  He had seen his own father run a legitimate ministry and raise money for a hospital in Africa.Â  He stated he had no criminal intent.Â  
Additionally, respondentâ€™s older brother, attorney Tom Greene, testified before the panel.Â  Tom, a former Greenville solicitor and former legislator, stated that his brother is â€œsomewhat gullible.â€Â  Respondent also presented several witnesses who testified or submitted affidavits regarding his good character and reputation as a lawyer.
Finally, respondent has no disciplinary history in almost 30 years as an attorney.Â  He cooperated with the federal investigation after he withdrew as Cabeâ€™s lawyer, and also cooperated with disciplinary counsel.Â  He turned over the remaining HIM money in his trust account to the federal restitution fund.Â 
DISCUSSION
The full panel decided respondent had engaged in misconduct and recommended that respondent: (1) be suspended from the practice of law for nine months; (2) pay the costs of the disciplinary proceedings; and (3) be required to take CLE courses regarding the proper use of trust accounts.Â  Respondent raises 18 exceptions to the report.[9]Â  While we agree with respondent that the evidence does not support all the rule violations found in the report,[10] we nonetheless find respondent committed misconduct and impose the recommended sanction.
The authority to discipline attorneys and the manner in which the discipline is given rests entirely with this Court. Â In re McFarland, 360 S.C. 101, 600 S.E.2d 537 (2004); In re Long, 346 S.C. 110, 551 S.E.2d 586 (2001).Â  A disciplinary violation must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  E.g., In re Chastain, 340 S.C. 356, 532 S.E.2d 264 (2000).Â  This Court is not bound by the sub-panelâ€™s recommendation; instead, after a thorough review of the record, the Court may make its own findings of fact and conclusions of law, and it must impose the sanction it deems appropriate.Â  In re McFarland, supra; In re Strickland, 354 S.C. 169, 172, 580 S.E.2d 126, 127 (2003); In re Chastain, supra.
It is clear to us that respondent committed professional misconduct by allowing Cabe and HIM to utilize his trust account with the knowledge that HIMâ€™s American bank accounts had been frozen as part of a federal criminal investigation.Â  This was a serious lapse in professional judgment which amounted to conduct â€œinvolving â€¦ fraudâ€ as well as conduct that was â€œprejudicial to the administration of justice.â€Â  Rules 8.4(d) & (e), of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR; see also Preamble: A Lawyerâ€™s Responsibilities, Rule 407, RPC (â€œA lawyer, being a member of the legal profession, is a representative of clients, an officer of the legal system and a public citizen having special responsibility for the quality of justice.â€).Â  
In addition to violations of Rules 8.4(d) & (e), RPC, we find that respondent also violated: Â Rule 1.8(a), RPC (conflict of interest, by entering into the business transaction with HIM while representing Cabe and HIM without the clientâ€™s written consent); and Rule 8.4(a), RPC (it is professional misconduct to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct).
Likewise, we find there clearly are grounds for discipline in this matter.Â  See Rules 7(a)(1) & (5), RLDE (â€œIt shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to: (1) violate â€¦ the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR,â€ and â€œ(5) engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law.â€)Â  
Accordingly, we order that respondent be definitely suspended for nine months and take CLE courses regarding the proper use of trust accounts.Â  In addition, respondent shall pay the costs of these disciplinary proceedings. Â Within 15 days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
Â DEFINITE SUSPENSION
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., conur.

[1] The federal district court sentenced Cabe to 109 monthsâ€™ imprisonment.Â  Respondent was not criminally charged.
[2] Respondent knew Smith through their work with The Gospel Hour, a legitimate, non-profit evangelical ministry started by respondentâ€™s father, Dr. Oliver Greene.Â  Originally a radio and tent evangelist, Dr. Greeneâ€™s ministry grew quite large, and today it continues to be broadcast on the radio and is even broadcast worldwide via the internet.Â  See http://www.thegospelhour.org/index.html.Â  After his fatherâ€™s death in 1976, respondent took over as executive director for The Gospel Hour.Â  He passed the bar and began practicing law in 1977.
[3] Disciplinary Counsel submitted HIMâ€™s promotional materials which detailed HIMâ€™s â€œunique secured asset high yield programs,â€ and explained â€œdebenture trading programsâ€ as virtually no-risk.Â  Respondent, however, did not see the HIM printed materials prior to his investment with, or representation of, HIM.
[4] Neither Smith nor Palmer was criminally charged in the HISway scheme.
[5] In addition to HIMâ€™s accounts being frozen, respondent also knew that Cabeâ€™s house had been searched pursuant to a federal search warrant.
[6] Since approximately 1991, respondent has been a solo practitioner.
[7] The remaining HISway money from respondentâ€™s trust account, $41,282.50, was contributed by respondent to the federal restitution fund later used to reimburse victims of the scam.
[8] As a plaintiff, Hagins (along with Barnes) brought a civil lawsuit against Cabe, respondent, and others, and eventually the matter was settled by respondentâ€™s malpractice carrier for $60,000.00.
[9] Respondent contends, inter alia, the Panel erroneously:Â  (1) applied a â€œknew or should have knownâ€ standard to the facts, and (2) imputed Cabeâ€™s intent to use respondentâ€™s trust account for illegal purposes to respondent.Â  
[10] Unlike the panel, we do not find respondent violated Rules 1.1, 1.2(d), 1.13(d), 1.16(b), and 8.4(b) & (c), of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Interest of Johnny Lee W., a minor under the age of seventeen, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Sumter County
Â R. Wright Turbeville, Family Court Judge
Â George M. McFaddin, Jr., Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26233
Heard October 5, 2006 - Filed December 4, 2006Â  

VACATED IN PART AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, of Columbia; and Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  In this appeal, we are asked whether the trial judge erred by accepting appellantâ€™s conditional guilty pleas.Â  We vacate in part and remand.
FACTS
Appellant was charged with disturbing school and threatening a public official in January 2004.Â  He filed a motion to quash the charge based on the unconstitutionality of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-420 (Supp. 2005), on the grounds it was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad.[1]Â  The motion was denied by Judge George McFaddin, Jr.
Subsequently, appellant was charged with disturbing school in September 2004, by hitting two students, and disturbing school on the same date by hitting a third student.[2]Â  Appellant filed a motion to quash these two charges on the same constitutional grounds.
Appellant pled guilty to the three charges of disturbing schools.Â  He entered a plea of no contest to the threatening a public official charge.Â  Finding he was bound by Judge McFaddinâ€™s earlier ruling on the motion to quash, Judge R. Wright Turbeville found that the statute is not unconstitutional.Â  Judge Turbeville adjudicated appellant a delinquent and accepted his pleas and remanded him to Reception and Evaluation for evaluation.
Appellant later appeared before Judge Turbeville for disposition and was sentenced to commitment to the Department of Juvenile Justice for an indeterminate period not to exceed his twenty-first birthday.Â  The sentence was suspended and appellant was placed on probation for one year.
ISSUE
Are appellantâ€™s guilty pleas invalid as conditional guilty pleas?
DISCUSSION
At the adjudicatory hearing, the following exchange occurred:

  COUNSEL:Â  . . . What Iâ€™m trying to do here is, in the interest of judicial economy and without putting the State to the task of a trial to prove that we engaged in conduct that would violate the statute if the statute were constitutional, is to simply stipulate to that, but continuing to maintain for and preserve our right to appeal.
  THE COURT:Â  To preserve your right to appeal Judge McFaddinâ€™s ruling.
  COUNSEL:Â  Yes, sir.
  THE COURT:Â  Okay.Â  The constitutionality of those statutes.
  COUNSEL:Â  Thatâ€™s the only thing weâ€™re trying to do today without having to take the courtâ€™s time to hear conduct we essentially admit to, but just say that itâ€™s not illegal.
  THE COURT:Â  You stipulate to the fact that if that statute is constitutional, that his conduct violated it?
  COUNSEL:Â  Yes, sir.

Thereafter, Judge Turbeville accepted appellantâ€™s guilty pleas.
Appellant argues the judge erred by accepting his disturbing schools guilty pleas because they were conditioned on his right to appeal the issue of whether the statute proscribing disturbing schools is unconstitutional.Â  The State conceded at oral argument that appellantâ€™s pleas were conditional.[3]
A trial court may not accept a conditional plea.Â  See State v. Truesdale, 278 S.C. 368, 296 S.E.2d 528 (1982) (conditional plea is a practice not recognized in South Carolina and a practice of which this Court expressly disapproves; if an accused attempts to attach any condition or qualification to a plea, the trial court should direct a plea of not guilty).Â  See also State v. Peppers, 346 S.C. 502, 552 S.E.2d 288 (2001) (court could not accept guilty plea where appellant conditioned guilty plea upon right to appeal constitutionality of indictment); State v. Oâ€™Leary, 302 S.C. 17, 393 S.E.2d 186 (1990) (court could not accept guilty plea where appellant conditioned guilty plea upon right to appeal constitutionality of statute).
Accordingly, the trial court erred by accepting the conditional pleas to the charges of disturbing school and those pleas are vacated.Â  Appellant argues that because all of his pleas were entered together and the sentence reflects a combination of the pleas, each of his pleas and sentence should be vacated.Â  However, appellant did not appeal his guilty plea to malicious injury to property, therefore, that plea is unaffected by his entering conditional pleas to the disturbing school charges.Â  Further, appellantâ€™s nolo contendere plea to threatening a public official was not entered as a conditional plea; therefore, it is not vacated.
Although there are two valid guilty pleas, appellantâ€™s sentence is vacated because it was a combination sentence for all of the charges against him.Â  On remand, the court may re-sentence appellant on the charges of malicious injury to property and threatening a public official.Â  If appellant chooses to re-plead to the disturbing schools charges without placing conditions on those pleas, then appellant may also be sentenced on those charges at that time, or he may choose to proceed to trial on those charges.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial judge is
VACATED IN PART AND REMANDED.

  TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]We recently held in the opinion of In the Interest of Amir X. S., Op. No. 26219 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed November 6, 2006) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 42 at 23), that the statute was not unconstitutional.
[2]Appellant was also charged with malicious injury to property.Â  He pled guilty and did not appeal that adjudication. 
[3]The State argues, however, that the issue is not preserved for review because appellant did not raise this issue at the later disposition hearing nor did he move to withdraw his pleas.Â  This contention is without merit.Â  See State v. Peppers, 346 S.C. 502, 552 S.E.2d 288 (2001) (conditional plea vacated although appellant had not moved to withdraw the plea); State v. Oâ€™Leary, 302 S.C. 17, 393 S.E.2d 186 (1990) (same).

description: In this post-conviction relief case, the Court found counsel ineffective for failing to request a continuance.
text:
Morris


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Phillip Morris, Petitioner
v.
State of South Carolina, Respondent
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26234
Submitted November 15, 2006 - Filed December 11, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Christopher L. Newton, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER: In this post-conviction relief (PCR) case, we granted certiorari to review the PCR courtâ€™s denial of relief to petitioner, Phillip Morris.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Petitioner was indicted for assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK). On July 9, 2002, the scheduled trial date, petitioner arrived at court and signed a sentencing sheet in anticipation of entering a guilty plea to the lesser-included charge of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN).[1]Â  Petitioner subsequently left the courthouse, and when his case was called, he could not be located.Â  When the State sought to try petitioner in absentia, petitionerâ€™s counsel told the trial court that she â€œwould prefer not to proceed withoutâ€ petitioner present.Â  The trial court ruled that by leaving the courthouse, petitioner had forfeited his rights.[2]Â  Petitionerâ€™s trial in absentia began immediately thereafter.
The trial concluded the next day, and the jury found petitioner guilty of ABIK.Â  The trial court sentenced him to 20 yearsâ€™ imprisonment, suspended upon the service of 15 years, and five yearsâ€™ probation.[3]Â  Petitioner did not directly appeal, but filed for PCR.Â  
At the PCR hearing, trial counsel testified that at some point after signing the plea sheet, petitioner left and could not be found when his case was called for the guilty plea.Â  Counsel denied telling petitioner he could leave the courthouse.Â  She further stated she did not realize she had not moved for a continuance after the State requested a trial in absentia.Â  
Petitioner testified that after he signed the plea sheet, he asked counsel if she could get a continuance.Â  According to petitioner, counsel said she would try; after a few minutes in the courtroom, she returned and told him he could go.Â  Petitioner stated that he waited for notification of a sentencing date and did not know his case had been tried until police picked him up on October 22, 2002.Â  
Petitionerâ€™s girlfriend, Jaclyn Cummings, also testified at the PCR hearing.Â  She was with petitioner at the courthouse on the day he signed the plea sheet.Â  Cummings stated she also understood that counsel was going to try to get the â€œpostponement,â€ and therefore, she and petitioner could leave.
The PCR court denied relief, specifically finding that (1) petitionerâ€™s testimony and the testimony of Cummings were not credible, while trial counselâ€™s testimony was credible; and (2) trial counsel â€œtried to postpone the trial, via a Motion for Continuance, but that Motion was denied.â€Â  
ISSUE
Did petitioner establish that trial counsel was ineffective?
DISCUSSION
Petitioner argues that counsel should have moved for a continuance.Â  Petitioner further contends he was prejudiced by counselâ€™s omission because he would have received a lesser sentence on the lesser charge of ABHAN.Â  We agree.
There is a strong presumption that counsel rendered adequate assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making all significant decisions in the case. Â Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984); Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989). Â In order to prove that counsel was ineffective, the PCR applicant must show that:Â  (1) counselâ€™s performance was deficient; and (2) there is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the result of the trial would have been different. Â Strickland v. Washington, supra; Rhodes v. State, 349 S.C. 25, 561 S.E.2d 606 (2002).
In a PCR proceeding, the burden is on the applicant to prove the allegations in his application.Â  E.g., Bannister v. State, 333 S.C. 298, 509 S.E.2d 807 (1998).Â  This Court will uphold the findings of the PCR court if there is any evidence of probative value to support them but will reverse the PCR courtâ€™s decision when it is controlled by an error of law. Â Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 145, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000); Cherry v. State, supra.
Initially, we note there is no evidence to support the PCR courtâ€™s finding that counsel tried to postpone the trial by moving for a continuance and therefore cannot uphold that finding.Â  Cherry v. State, supra.Â  While the trial transcript clearly shows counsel objected to proceeding with a trial in absentia, this is markedly different from counsel making a motion for a continuance so petitioner could plead guilty to ABHAN as had been agreed upon between petitioner and the State.Â  Consequently, we find counsel was deficient for failing to request a continuance.
The State contends, however, that petitioner cannot establish prejudice because the trial court was disinclined to grant a continuance since petitioner had left the courthouse.Â  The State further maintains that because reversals of the denial of a continuance are â€œabout as rare as the proverbial hensâ€™ teeth,â€ petitioner failed to meet the prejudice prong.Â  State v. Lytchfield, 230 S.C. 405, 409, 95 S.E.2d 857, 859 (1957).Â  We disagree.
The trial courtâ€™s refusal of a motion for continuance in a criminal case will not be disturbed absent a clear abuse of discretion resulting in prejudice to the appellant.Â  State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 459, 469 S.E.2d 49, 51 (1996); Lytchfield, supra.Â  Here, it is clear petitioner would have been prejudiced by the denial of a continuance because the trial in absentia subjected him to the ABIK conviction whereas the guilty plea would have been to ABHAN.Â  The difference between these two crimes is significant.Â  ABHAN is a common law misdemeanor punishable by up to ten years in prison, while ABIK is a violent crime felony punishable by up to twenty years in prison. Â See State v. Fennell, 340 S.C. 266, 274-75, 531 S.E.2d 512, 516 (2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 16-1-60, 16-3-620 (2003). Â Given the drastic distinctions between a conviction of ABIK versus one of ABHAN, we find this is the rare case where the refusal of the continuance would have amounted to an abuse of discretion.Â  See State v. Williams, supra; Lytchfield, supra.Â  Thus, we find petitioner established prejudice from counselâ€™s deficient performance.Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold counsel did not move for a continuance and that the failure to do so prejudiced petitioner.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the PCR courtâ€™s denial of relief and remand for a new trial.

REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: Armstrong v. Food Lion
description: This case involves the issue of whether the Court of Appeals erred by finding the trial court properly directed a verdict in Food Lion's favor on petitioners' cause of action alleging Food Lion was vicariously liable for the torts committed by its employees.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Ronnie Armstrong and Tillie Armstrong, Petitioners,
v.
Food Lion, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI
TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26235
Heard November 1, 2006 - Filed December 11, 2006Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Katherine Carruth Link, of West Columbia, and Ross Alan Burton, of Winnsboro, for petitioners.
D. Andrew Williams, and R. Hawthorne Barrett, of Turner, Padget, Graham, & Laney, P.A., of Columbia; and Paul D. Harrill, of McNair Law Firm, P.A., of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Petitioners, who are mother and son, filed suit against respondent (Food Lion), alleging causes of action for assault, battery, outrage, premises liability, negligence, and negligence per se.Â  The trial court granted Food Lionâ€™s motion for a directed verdict as to most of petitionersâ€™ claims.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of Food Lion as to the negligence claim.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR.Â  Armstrong v. Food Lion, Inc., Op. No. 2004-UP-366 (S.C. Ct. App. filed June 10, 2004).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Petitioner Ronnie Armstrong (Ronnie) went to the Winnsboro Food Lion store on December 14, 1998, to purchase groceries with his sister and his mother Tillie Armstrong (Tillie).Â  As Ronnie walked up the aisle of the store, three men in Food Lion uniforms approached him.Â  Ronnie stated that Byron Brown approached and said â€œWhatâ€™s up?,â€ and Ronnie replied, â€œNothing.â€Â  Ronnie testified that Brown then attacked him with a box cutter.Â  Brown cut Ronnie in the face and neck and a second employee, Marcus Cameron, also began attacking him after he fell on the floor.Â  Cameron cut him with another box cutter on his back.
When Ronnieâ€™s mother, Tillie, came to his aid, Cameron punched her in the chest and knocked her to the floor.Â  A witness, Justin Loner, helped Tillie up and pulled Cameron off of Ronnie.Â  Brown then backed off, and Loner called EMS.Â  Ronnie testified that, â€œI donâ€™t know why they cut me.Â  They just attacked me for no reason.Â  I said nothing to provoke anyone.â€Â  On cross-examination, Ronnie stated he had a confrontation with Brown two years prior to the incident, and Brown had threatened to kill him.Â  
Loner testified that, when he first entered Food Lion, he saw three employees at the front of the store â€œgoofing offâ€ and not working.Â  Two of those employees were Brown and Cameron.Â  He stated that, after Ronnie and the employees approached each other, he saw one employee hit Ronnie causing him to bleed.
The store manager testified regarding the Food Lion employee manual.Â  He read from the manual under the heading â€œCase Cutters.â€Â  The manual stated:Â  â€œBe extremely careful when using case cutters.Â  Case cutters represent one of the major causes of accidents in the supermarket.â€
Following the presentation of petitionersâ€™ case, Food Lion moved for a directed verdict, arguing petitioners had failed to present evidence that Brown and Cameron were acting within the scope of their employment at the time of the assault.Â  During petitionersâ€™ argument in response, counsel admitted Brown and Cameron â€œwere goofing off at the time.â€Â  The trial court granted a directed verdict in Food Lionâ€™s favor as to petitionersâ€™ causes of action for assault, assault and battery, and outrage[1] based on petitionersâ€™ failure to show the assault was committed for the purpose of, or in some way furthering, Food Lionâ€™s business.
ISSUE

Did the Court of Appeals err by finding the trial court properly directed a verdict in Food Lionâ€™s favor on petitionersâ€™ cause of action alleging Food Lion was vicariously liable for the torts committed by its employees?

DISCUSSION
In ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions.Â  Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Reg., 336 S.C. 373, 520 S.E.2d 142 (1999). Â If the evidence as a whole is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the motion should have been denied.Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 585 S.E.2d 281 (2003).Â  This Court will reverse only where there is no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling, or where the ruling was controlled by an error of law.Â  Steinke, supra.
Petitioners contend Food Lion is legally responsible to them for the acts of its employees, Brown and Cameron.Â  The doctrine of respondeat superior rests upon the relation of master and servant.Â  Lane v. Modern Music, Inc., 244 S.C. 299, 136 S.E.2d 713 (1964).Â  A plaintiff seeking recovery from the master for injuries must establish
that the relationship existed at the time of the injuries, and also that the servant was then about his masterâ€™s business and acting within the scope of his employment.Â  Id.Â  An act is within the scope of a servantâ€™s employment where reasonably necessary to accomplish the purpose of his employment and in furtherance of the masterâ€™s business.Â  Id.Â  These general principles govern in determining whether an employer is liable for the acts of his servant.Â  Id.
The act of a servant done to effect some independent purpose of his own and not with reference to the service in which he is employed, or while he is acting as his own master for the time being, is not within the scope of his employment so as to render the master liable therefor.Â  Lane, supra.Â  Under these circumstances the servant alone is liable for the injuries inflicted.Â  Id.Â  If a servant steps aside from the masterâ€™s business for some purpose wholly disconnected with his employment, the relation of master and servant is temporarily suspended; this is so no matter how short the time, and the master is not liable for his acts during such time.Â  Id.
The trial court appropriately granted a directed verdict because petitioners failed to produce any evidence that the Food Lion employees were acting within the scope of their employment or in furtherance of Food Lionâ€™s business when they attacked petitioners.Â  The only reasonable inference from the testimony is that Brown and Cameron attacked Ronnie for their own personal reasons and not for any reason related to their employment.[2]Â  They were acting â€œto effect an independent purpose of their own.â€Â  See Lane, supra (act of servant done to effect some independent purpose of his own is not within scope of his employment).Â  Food Lion was not legally liable because the employees stepped away from their job of stocking shelves.Â  See Lane, supra (employer not liable where employee stepped away from the employerâ€™s business to play a prank); Hamilton v. Davis, 300 S.C. 411, 389 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 1990) (same).
Two cases that have previously found an employer liable for its employeeâ€™s assault of another person are distinguishable from the instant case.Â  In Crittenden v. Thompson-Walker Co., Inc., 288 S.C. 112, 341 S.E.2d 385 (Ct. App. 1986), an employee assaulted another person in an attempt to collect a debt of the business.Â  In Jones v. Elbert, 211 S.C. 553, 34 S.E.2d 796 (1945), a dairy farmâ€™s general manager assaulted the owner of a company contracted to provide a refrigerating system.Â  The assault resulted from a dispute arising over problems with the system.Â  The factor that distinguishes these cases from the instant case is that the assaults in Jones and Crittenden occurred, not merely in connection with the masterâ€™s business, but with the purpose of in some way furthering the masterâ€™s business.Â  Here, there is no evidence that Brown and Cameron were furthering Food Lionâ€™s business in any manner.[3]Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly granted Food Lionâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  Therefore, the decision of the Court of Appeals is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]The causes of action for negligence per se and premises liability were also dismissed.Â  
[2]Petitioners argue that, because the reason for the attack is not gleaned from the testimony, we should look at the evidence in the light most favorable to them and essentially find the attack occurred for a work-related reason and send the case to the jury.Â  However, this argument ignores the fact that petitioners have the burden of proving the employees were about Food Lionâ€™s business and acting within the scope of their employment at the time of the attack.Â  Petitioners failed to meet this burden.
[3]Petitioners argue the evidence was sufficient to establish a presumption that the employees were acting within the scope of their employment because Food Lion had furnished the instrumentalities used in the attack.Â  Where one is found in possession of anotherâ€™s property, apparently using it in the business of such other, he is presumed to be the agent or servant of the owner and acting within the course of his employment.Â  See Falconer v. Beard-Laney, Inc., 215 S.C. 321, 54 S.E.2d 904 (1949).Â  However, petitioners failed to show that the employees were using the box cutters in Food Lionâ€™s business.Â  Therefore, petitioners are not entitled to any such presumption.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Kenneth L. Edwards, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26236
Submitted November 2, 2006 - Filed December 11, 2006

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
Kenneth L. Edwards, of Hollywood, pro se.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to imposition of any sanction set forth in Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the agreement and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law for eighteen months.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
In 1986, respondent and his wife were divorced in North Carolina.Â  The order included a requirement that respondent pay $300.00 per month in child support.Â  Respondent did not appeal the North Carolina order.Â  
In 1987, respondent filed a separate action for divorce in South Carolina.Â  In the South Carolina proceedings, respondent obtained an order that provided for $200.00 per month in child support.Â  
At the time the North Carolina and South Carolina orders were issued, respondent was not an attorney.Â  Even after becoming an attorney, respondent did not fully comply with either the North Carolina or South Carolina support orders, although he did make some payments pursuant to the South Carolina order.[1]
In 2001, the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) filed an action to register and enforce the North Carolina order.[2]Â  The action alleged respondent was in arrears in excess of $94,000.00.Â  Respondent responded to the DSS action by challenging the validity of the North Carolina order.Â  The judge held the North Carolina order was valid and ordered respondent to make payments.Â  The decision was upheld on appeal.Â  Only then did respondent begin to make payments pursuant to the North Carolina order.Â  
In 2004, at the time respondentâ€™s appeal in the DSS action was pending, respondent sued his ex-wife in the Court of Common Pleas in South Carolina, contesting the validity of the North Carolina order and requesting termination of child support.Â  The action was dismissed for lack of jurisdiction. 
In 2004, respondent also filed a motion to terminate child support on the grounds of his sonâ€™s emancipation.Â  Respondent attached an affidavit and itemized list to his motion to terminate stating he had already paid, directly and indirectly, over $30,000.00 in support.Â  The itemized list of payments contained a statement that respondent had paid over $14,000.00 in tuition payments to a military school for respondentâ€™s son.Â  Although respondent had paid the tuition, the son did not attend the school and respondent obtained a full refund.Â  Respondent was refunded the money more than three years prior to his submission of the affidavit to the court.Â  Respondent did not inform the court that he had received a full refund of the tuition.Â  Respondent admits the judge relied on his affidavit and the itemized list when she considered his motion to terminate his support obligation.Â  
In respondentâ€™s motion for termination, respondent used the case caption from his 1987 South Carolina divorce action rather than the case caption for the pending DSS support enforcement action.Â  Respondent served his ex-wife, but not DSS, even though he knew that DSS was assigned the rights to his child support.Â  When the ex-wife did not appear at the hearing on respondentâ€™s motion to terminate payments, respondent handed up a proposed order which the judge signed.Â  The order indicated that respondent had paid his child support pursuant to the South Carolina order and terminated support.Â  Respondent did not inform the judge of the North Carolina support order, the pending DSS enforcement action and appeal, or the alleged arrearage to the judge.Â  When the judge learned of the DSS action, she vacated the termination order she had signed for respondent.Â  Â 
On December 6, 2004, respondent filed a civil action against his ex-wife alleging, among other things, malicious prosecution and â€œmisuse of legal procedure.â€Â  He included a cause of action based, in part, on an ethical grievance his ex-wife had filed against him in 1995.Â  The rules in effect at the time the grievance was filed prohibited lawyers from disclosing disciplinary matters.Â  Respondent neither sought nor obtained permission from this Court to reveal information regarding his ex-wifeâ€™s grievance. Â In addition, respondentâ€™s claims of malicious prosecution and â€œmisuse of legal procedureâ€ based on the grievance were without merit and in violation of Rule 13, RLDE (formerly Rule 26 of the Rule on Disciplinary Procedure) which provided immunity to complainants in disciplinary matters.Â Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 3.1 (lawyer shall not bring, assert, or controvert an issue in a proceeding unless there is a basis for doing so that is not frivolous); Rule 3.3 (lawyer shall not knowingly fail to disclose a material fact to a tribunal when disclosure is necessary to avoid assisting in a fraudulent act); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation); and
Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).
Â In addition, respondent admits his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline pursuant to Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers), Rule 7(a)(5) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law), and Rule 7(a)(7) (lawyer shall not willfully violate a valid court order issued by a court of this state or of another jurisdiction).Â  Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law for eighteen months.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur

[1] Respondent was admitted to the South Carolina Bar on June 1, 1992.Â  
[2] By that time, the order had been registered in Michigan, the ex-wifeâ€™s new place of residence.

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Benjamin R. Matthews, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26237
Submitted October 31, 2006 - Filed December 11, 2006Â

Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.

PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to either an admonition or a public reprimand. Â Respondent further agrees to pay the costs associated with ODCâ€™s investigation into this matter. Â We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  Within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall fully reimburse ODC for its costs associated with its investigation into this matter.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Matter I
Respondent represented Buyer in a real estate closing.Â  Seller, who lived out of state, was represented by another attorney for the purposes of deed preparation.Â  Sellerâ€™s attorney was to have the deed executed and delivered to respondentâ€™s non-lawyer assistant for recording at the courthouse after closing.
Prior to the closing, Sellerâ€™s attorney faxed respondent the signed deed which listed Buyer and his wife â€œas joint tenants with right of survivorship and not as tenants in commonâ€ (Deed #1).Â  This was in accordance with the instructions Sellerâ€™s attorney received from the broker.Â  Upon review of Deed #1 and at the request of Buyer and his wife, respondent contacted Sellerâ€™s attorney prior to closing and asked that the grantee be changed to Buyer only.Â  The Sellerâ€™s attorney then faxed a revised but unsigned deed for respondentâ€™s review (Deed #2).Â Â  
Sellerâ€™s attorney did not hear back from respondent regarding her fax.Â  Accordingly, Deed #2 was not executed.Â  Instead, Sellerâ€™s attorney delivered Deed #1 to the courthouse as planned.Â  Deed #1 was recorded on September 21, 2004.
At some time prior to recordation, Deed #1 was altered to strike out Buyerâ€™s wifeâ€™s name, but not the tenancy clause.Â  It is unknown who altered Deed #1; however, there is no evidence that it was done by respondent or Sellerâ€™s attorney or at their direction.Â  Apparently, it was altered by a staff person attempting to comply with Buyerâ€™s request to have the property titled in his name alone. 
When Buyer received the recorded deed, he compared it to the copy he had been given by respondentâ€™s staff at closing.Â  Apparently, Buyer had been given the first page of the correctly worded deed faxed to respondent prior to closing (Deed #2) with the tenancy clause whited out so as to make it appear that Buyer was the sole grantee.Â  Although the alteration of the copy provided to Buyer was not done by respondent or at his direction, respondent admits that it was done by a non-lawyer subject to his supervision.
Respondent acknowledges that by accepting more legal work than he and his staff could competently and diligently handle, he created an atmosphere in which his non-lawyer staff believed it was appropriate to attempt to resolve problems, such as the problem with Buyerâ€™s deed, without his assistance or review.Â Â  
Matter II
On June 23, 2004, respondent conducted a real estate closing.Â  As of June 27, 2005, respondent had not provided the lender with the closing documents, including the recorded mortgage, the final title opinion, and the final title opinion.Â  Respondent failed to respond to repeated letters and telephone calls from the lender and its attorney inquiring into the status of the closing documents.Â  It was not until October 2005, after this grievance was filed, that respondent sent the documents to the lender.Â  Although the mortgage had been timely filed, the delay resulted in respondentâ€™s untimely issuance of final title opinions and policies.Â  
Respondent admits that, at times, he was more than two years behind in issuing some final title opinions and policies.Â  The backlog involved as many as 700 files and more than $40,000 in premiums.Â  
Respondent has now left private practice.Â  Before closing out his books, he hired staff to assist him in preparation and issuance of all outstanding title insurance opinions and policies.Â  
Matter III
Respondent delegated the responsibility of reconciling his trust accounts to a non-lawyer assistant without providing proper training or supervision.Â  Although the accounts were reconciled every month, the non-lawyer assistant was not given appropriate instruction about how to recognize potential errors requiring respondentâ€™s attention.Â  As a result, for more than seven (7) months respondent was not made aware of three significant deposit errors in October, November, and December 2004.Â  In each of these months, incoming funds were deposited into the wrong account.Â  Disbursements were made from the correct account, causing the balance in that account to drop below the amounts respondent should have maintained for other pending matters.Â  Because the account contained a substantial balance of unpaid title insurance premiums, no checks were returned.
When respondent discovered the errors, he transferred the deposited funds into the correct account.Â  Although no client or third party suffered any loss, respondent acknowledges that he created significant risk of loss to others by failing to adequately manage his trust account.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing client); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall safe keep client funds and property); and Rule 5.3 (lawyer having authority over non-lawyer assistant shall make reasonable efforts to ensure personâ€™s conduct is compatible with professional obligations).Â  Respondent further admits his conduct violated the recordkeeping provisions of Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.Â  Within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall fully reimburse ODC for its costs associated with its investigation into this matter.
 PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
