Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this case, the trial court denied Appellant Martha Bandaâ€™s pre-trial motions to suppress evidence and an incriminating statement she gave to police.Â  The trial court subsequently convicted Banda for trafficking in ten grams or more of methamphetamine and sentenced her to four years imprisonment.Â  
Factual/Procedural Background
In February 2003, Banda, a citizen of Zimbabwe,[1] was a passenger in a car stopped by the City of Greenville (Greenville) police for having stolen Georgia license tags.Â  Earlier that evening, Greenville narcotics officers Detective Mark White (White) and Detective Melissa Lawson (Lawson) were staking out a house that a confidential informant had told them was the residence of a female drug target dealing methamphetamines, and for whom the officers had an arrest warrant.Â  The confidential informant had arranged to purchase an â€œ8-ball of methâ€ at the targetâ€™s house.Â  The informant further told police that the drugs came from a supplier in Georgia.Â  
During the stakeout, the narcotics officers observed a car with Georgia license tags pull into the driveway of the targetâ€™s residence and leave thirty to forty minutes later.Â  Although Whiteâ€™s testimony indicates that at this point, the officers were aware of the possibility that the deal between the confidential informant and the target had been called off, they followed the car assuming that the occupants might be going to meet with the informant anyway.Â  As the officers continued to follow the vehicle, they realized there were two occupants:Â  a male driver and a female passenger.Â  White and Lawson testified that at this point, they assumed the female passenger to be their target.Â  After learning from dispatch that the Georgia tags had been reported stolen, White and Lawson had another uniformed Greenville police officer assist them in stopping the car once it entered the city limits.Â  Detective Conroy (Conroy), another narcotics officer assisting in the investigation of the target, also came to the scene.Â  
Upon stopping the car, the officers requested that both the driver and passenger step out of the car.Â  Conroy and the uniformed officer attended to the driver and subsequently handcuffed and arrested him for driving with a stolen license plate.Â  Meanwhile, White and Lawson approached Banda on the passenger side.Â  Although the officers immediately realized Banda was not their target when she stepped out of the car, they proceeded to question her at the scene anyway. 
Detective White had his gun drawn and pointed at Banda as Lawson asked her if she had any weapons.[2]Â  Banda responded she did not, but Lawson explained to Banda she was going to do a routine pat down for Lawsonâ€™s own safety.Â  During the pat down, Lawson felt an object in Bandaâ€™s upper right hand coat pocket.Â  When Lawson asked Banda what it was, Banda explained that it was her ace bandage.Â  At the same time, Banda pulled a â€œloosely rolled upâ€ bandage out of the pocket and handed it to Lawson.Â  Lawson squeezed the bandage and felt plastic on the inside. She looked at Banda who â€œdropped her headâ€ and told Lawson it was an ounce of â€œice.â€Â  Lawson read Banda her Miranda rights at the scene and after a further search of the vehicle, the officers took Banda back to the station where they read her Miranda rights for a second time.Â  After waiving her Miranda rights, Banda gave the officers a written statement.Â  
Banda made a pre-trial motion to suppress the drugs found by Lawson on the grounds that Lawsonâ€™s stop and frisk was an unreasonable search and seizure.Â  After an in camera suppression hearing in which the trial court heard testimony from Banda and Detectives White and Lawson, the court denied Bandaâ€™s motion to suppress the drugs.Â  The trial court found the police had probable cause to stop the car for the stolen tags; they had the authority to request Banda to get out of the car; and that Banda was properly frisked for weapons given the officersâ€™ reasonable suspicion of her involvement in the delivery of drugs. 
Banda then made a second pre-trial motion to suppress her written statement made to the police after her arrest.Â  Banda argued she had not been informed of her right to contact Zimbabweâ€™s consular official as required by international treaty.Â  The State did not deny this allegation.Â  
The trial court found that even assuming the Greenville officers had violated the treaty, this violation did not provide adequate legal grounds to consider applying the exclusionary rule to Bandaâ€™s statement.Â  For this reason, the trial court refused to grant Banda a suppression hearing on the admissibility of her statement and denied her motion to suppress the statement.Â  The trial court subsequently sentenced Banda to four years imprisonment.Â  
This case was certified to this Court from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  Banda raises the following issues for review:

  
    
      I. 
       Did the trial court err in refusing to suppress the drugs found on Banda during a frisk for weapons pursuant to an automobile stop for a traffic violation?Â Â 
        
        
    
    
      II.
       Did the trial court err in refusing to grant a suppression hearing for Bandaâ€™s written statement to police when police failed to notify the foreign consulate of Bandaâ€™s arrest prior to interrogating her?
    
  

Standard of Review 
In criminal cases, an appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  Therefore, an appellate court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  The same standard of review applies to preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  Our review in Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases is limited to determining whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s finding.Â  State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 389, 577 S.E.2d 498, 500 (2003).
Law/Analysis
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Suppression of Drugs
Banda argues that the trial court erred in refusing to suppress the drugs found in her coat during the automobile stop.Â  We disagree.
The Fourth Amendment guarantees â€œthe right of the people to be secure
in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures.â€Â  U.S. Const., amend. IV.Â  Temporary detention of individuals by the police during an automobile stop constitutes a â€œseizureâ€ of an individual within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment.Â 
Delaware v. Prouse, 440 U.S. 648, 653 (1979).Â  Therefore, an automobile stop implicates the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures, imposing a standard of â€œreasonablenessâ€ upon the exercise of discretion by state law enforcement officials.Â  See id. at 654.Â  The decision to stop an automobile is reasonable where the police have probable cause to believe that a traffic violation has occurred.Â  Whren v. United States, 517 U.S. 806, 809-810 (1996).Â  Notwithstanding multiple exceptions, evidence obtained by searches and seizures in violation of the Constitution is inadmissible in a state court.Â  Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U.S. 643, 655 (1961). 
In this case, it is undisputed that Greenville police acted lawfully in stopping the car in which Banda was a passenger.Â  The car displayed a stolen license tag, and the stop occurred within the Greenville city limits, which was within Greenville police jurisdiction.[3]Â  Additionally, both parties acknowledge that the Greenville police were entitled to order Banda out of the car.Â  See Maryland v. Wilson, 519 U.S. 408, 415 (1997) (holding that a police officer may order both the driver and passenger out of the vehicle pursuant to a valid automobile stop without violating the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable seizures).Â  However, Banda argues that Detective Lawson did not have reasonable suspicion to search her for weapons.Â  For this reason, Banda contends the drugs recovered during the pat down should be suppressed.
Balancing the potential intrusion on an individualâ€™s Fourth Amendment rights with the need for law enforcement officers to protect themselves and other prospective victims of violence, the United States Supreme Court held in Terry v. Ohio that a police officer must have a reasonable suspicion that a person is armed and dangerous before conducting a pat down or frisk of that person.Â  392 U.S. 1, 24 (1968).Â  â€œReasonable suspicionâ€ of weapons requires that a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances be warranted in the belief that his safety or that of others is in danger.Â  Id. at 27; Butler, 353 S.C. at 390, 577 S.E.2d at 501. Â The Supreme Court extended the Terry doctrine to frisks pursuant to valid automobile stops for traffic violations in Pennsylvania v. Mimms, 434 U.S. 106, 111-112 (1977).Â  
We hold that under the circumstances of this case, Lawson had reasonable suspicion to frisk Banda for weapons pursuant to a valid automobile stop.Â  This Court has recognized that because of the â€œindisputable nexus between drugs and guns,â€ where an officer has reasonable suspicion that drugs are present in a vehicle[4] lawfully stopped, there is an appropriate level of suspicion of criminal activity and apprehension of danger to justify a frisk of both the driver and the passenger in the absence of other factors alleviating the officerâ€™s safety concerns.Â 
Butler, 353 S.C. at 391 (quoting U.S. v. Sakyi, 160 F.3d 164, 169-170 (4th Cir. 1998)).Â  In this situation, the police clearly had reasonable suspicion to suspect that drugs were present in the vehicle.Â  The police had observed the car leave the residence of a known drug dealer.Â  Furthermore, the car displayed stolen Georgia license tags and the police knew from their confidential informant that the targetâ€™s drug shipments came from Georgia.Â  Even though the police shortly realized that Banda was not their target, the fact that the activity observed at the targetâ€™s house corroborated the informantâ€™s statements was enough to give the officers a reasonable suspicion that Banda was in some way involved with the targetâ€™s drug activity and that drugs might therefore be in the vehicle.Â  See Cortez, 449 U.S. at 417.Â  Given the frequent association between drugs and guns, Lawsonâ€™s safety concerns were justified based on the vehicleâ€™s apparent connection to a known drug dealer.Â  
Banda compares her case to State v. Butler where this Court granted the defendantâ€™s motion to suppress drugs found in a frisk while he was a passenger in a vehicle stopped for having no taillights.Â  353 S.C. at 385, 577 S.E.2d at 499.Â  We find, however, that Butler
is distinguished given that the frisk in that case occurred as a part of the officerâ€™s continuing investigation of a possible open-container violation.Â 
Id. at 392; 577 S.E.2d at 503.Â  The Greenville police had what the officer in Butler
did not; that is, a reasonable suspicion that the suspect was armed and dangerous.Â  Their reasonable suspicion arose directly from the presumption of weapons when there is reasonable suspicion that drugs are present.Â  See id. at 391; 577 S.E.2d at 502.Â  
Accordingly, we hold that the trial court properly determined the officerâ€™s frisk for weapons was appropriate under Terry v. Ohio and did not violate the Fourth Amendment prohibition on unreasonable searches and seizures.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Suppression of Appellantâ€™s Statement
Banda argues that the trial court erred in refusing to grant a Jackson v. Denno[5] hearing on the admissibility of her statement to the police because the statement was taken in violation of an international treaty. Â This is an incorrect statement of the issue.Â  
At trial, Banda moved for an in camera suppression hearing for her statement to police on the grounds that police obtained the statement in violation of an international treaty.Â  The motion, as Banda presented it, did not involve a determination of the voluntariness of the statement:Â  Banda neither specifically requested a Jackson v. Denno hearing, nor did she otherwise support the motion with facts showing that the statement was involuntary.[6]Â  Bandaâ€™s claim that the trial court erred by refusing to grant her a Jackson v. Denno hearing is therefore not properly before the Court on appeal because the grounds now asserted are not supported by the motion made at trial.Â  See State v. Silver, 314 S.C. 483, 487, 431 S.E.2d 250, 252 (1993) (holding that the court of appeals improperly treated the trial courtâ€™s denial of an in camera hearing on the issue of whether defendant was in custody and entitled to Miranda warnings as the denial of a Jackson v. Denno hearing on the voluntariness of defendantâ€™s statement).
A more accurate statement of the issue preserved to this Court is whether the trial court erred by refusing to grant Banda an in camera suppression hearing on the admissibility of her statement to police based upon a violation of a bilateral consular convention between the United States and the United Kingdom[7] (the U.K. Convention) requiring consular notification when foreign nationals are detained.Â  
This is not the first time that South Carolina courts have analyzed the effects of international treaties on South Carolina law.Â  In State v. Lopez, the court of appeals addressed the consular notification provision in Article 36 of the Vienna Convention.[8]Â  352 S.C. 373, 574 S.E.2d 210 (2002).Â  In Lopez, the trial court denied the defendantâ€™s motion to withdraw his guilty plea where the State did not inform him of his consular notification rights under Article 36.Â  The defendant claimed that had he known of his rights, he would have obtained the services of a translator from the Mexican Consulate to assist him during his guilty plea hearing.Â  Although the Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution provides that treaties to which the United States is a party take precedence over any state law, the court of appeals noted that the rights created in international treaties did not create rights equivalent to constitutional rights.Â 
Id. at 381, 574 S.E.2d at 214.Â  Therefore, the defendant had to establish prejudice to prevail on his claim.Â  Id.Â  On these principles, the court of appeals affirmed the circuit court, observing that because the defendant had rejected the trial judgeâ€™s offers to provide him a translator, any prejudice suffered by the defendant from his failure to have a translatorâ€™s assistance during the guilty plea hearing resulted from his own actions.Â  Id. at 383, 574 S.E.2d at 215.
Recently, the United States Supreme Court addressed Article 36 of the Vienna Convention and its role in state judicial proceedings with respect to triggering the exclusionary rule.Â  In Sanchez-Llamas v. Oregon, 548 U.S. ____, 126 S.Ct. 2669 (2006), the court held that suppression of evidence was not an appropriate remedy for violations of Article 36 of the Vienna Convention for a number of reasons.Â  First, the court observed that the Vienna Convention did not mandate suppression or any other remedy for its violations, but rather left Article 36â€™s implementation to domestic law.Â  548 U.S. at ___, 126 S.Ct. at 2678 (quoting Art. 36(2), 21 U.S.T. at 101).Â  Furthermore, the court declared that it did not hold a supervisory authority over state courts that would permit it to develop remedies for the enforcement of federal law in state court criminal proceedings.Â  Id. at ___; 126 S.Ct. at 2679.Â  Without this power, the court reasoned that it could not direct the state courts to apply the exclusionary rule unless required to do so by the Vienna Convention itself (pursuant to the Supremacy Clause).Â  Lastly, the court stated that even if Article 36 implicitly required some judicial remedy for its violation (as Sanchez-Llamas claimed), the exclusionary rule would not be appropriate.Â  The court noted that the exclusionary ruleâ€™s primary function was to deter constitutional violations.Â  Article 36, in contrast, only secured the right to inform the foreign consulate of an arrest or detention; it did not guarantee any sort of consulate intervention or termination of investigation pending notice to or intervention by the consulate.Â Â 
Id. at ___, 126 S.Ct. at 2681.Â  With respect to interrogations, the court specifically stated that there was likely to be little connection between an Article 36 violation and statements obtained by police.Â Â  Id.Â  Suppression, it concluded, â€œwould be a vastly disproportionate remedy for an Article 36 violation.â€Â  Id.
Turning to the instant case, we hold that the trial judge properly refused to grant Banda a suppression hearing on the admissibility of her statements to police.Â  Whenever evidence is introduced that was allegedly obtained by conduct violative of the defendantâ€™s constitutional rights, the defendant is entitled to have the trial judge conduct an evidentiary hearing out of the presence of the jury to establish the circumstances under which the evidence was seized.Â Â  State v. Patton, 322 S.C. 408, 411, 472 S.E.2d 245, 247 (1996) (citing Jackson v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368). To be entitled to a suppression hearing, a defendant must articulate specific factual and legal grounds to support his claim that evidence was obtained by conduct violative of his constitutional rights.Â 
Id. at 411-412, 472 S.E.2d at 247.Â  In making this determination, the trial court shall take into account the totality of the circumstances and may eliminate those issues not raising a question of constitutionality while confining the hearing to those which have arguable merit.Â 
Id. at 412, 472 S.E.2d at 247.Â  
Bandaâ€™s only factual ground for her motion - correctly stated - is that police violated the U.K. Convention by not informing her of her right to notify Zimbabweâ€™s foreign consulate. Â Federal and state case law indicate this does not provide a valid legal ground on which to base her suppression claim.Â  Because the Vienna Conventionâ€™s consular notification provision is nearly the same as that in the U.K. Convention, the legal analyses in Lopez and Sanchez-Llamas apply equally to Article 16 of the U.K. Convention.[9]Â  Like the Vienna Convention, the U.K. Convention does not mandate suppression or any other remedy for its violations.[10]Â Â  Additionally, because international treaties do not create rights equivalent to constitutional rights, Lopez, 352 S.C. at 381, 574 S.E.2d at 214, the violation of the consular notification provision does not, on its own, justify applying the exclusionary rule as a remedy.Â  See Sanchez-Llamas, 548 U.S. at ___, 126 S.Ct. 2669.Â  Because the U.K. Convention only secures the right to inform the foreign consulate of a detention - and not the right to consular intervention - the violation of the U.K. Conventionâ€™s consular notification provision would have little connection with a defendantâ€™s statement to police.[11]Â  See id. at ___, 126 S.Ct. at 2681.Â  
With no other legal grounds in support of her motion to suppress her statement, applying the exclusionary rule to remedy the treaty violation would be â€œvastly disproportionateâ€ to any wrong suffered by Banda.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in denying Banda a suppression hearing on the admissibility of her statement to police. 
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the decision of the trial court.
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Banda came to the United States on a basketball scholarship.Â  She first attended a university in Oklahoma and later transferred to the University of South Carolina.Â  
[2] Detective White testified that it is routine police department practice to have guns drawn for car stops related to narcotics investigations.Â Â  Because the officers initially believed that Banda was their target, they adhered to this practice in approaching Banda during the stop.
[3] We note that â€œ[s]ubjective intentions play no role in ordinary, probable-cause Fourth Amendment analysis.â€Â  Whren, 517 U.S. at 814.Â  Evidence that the Greenville officers were more interested in apprehending the drug target does not factor into a probable cause analysis in the otherwise valid stop of a vehicle for stolen license tags.
[4] â€œReasonable suspicionâ€ in this context requires an officer to have â€œa particularized and objective basis,â€ based on the totality of the circumstances, that would lead one to suspect that drugs are present in the vehicle lawfully stopped.Â 
U.S. v. Cortez, 449 U.S. 411, 417 (1981); State v. Lesley, 326 S.C. 641, 644, 486 S.E.2d 276, 277 (Ct. App. 1997).
[5] Jackson v. Denno held that a defendant in a criminal case was entitled to an evidentiary hearing on the voluntariness of statements made by the defendant prior to submission of such statements to a jury.Â  378 U.S. 368 (1964).
[6] Banda did not dispute the validity of the Miranda warnings or her signed waiver.Â  Moreover, the State pointed out that Banda was college-educated and was not intoxicated that evening.Â  
[7] Banda based her motion to suppress the statement to police on the alleged violation of a consular notification provision in Article 36 of the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, April 24, 1963, 21 U.S.T. 77, T.I.A.S. No. 6820 [hereinafter Vienna Convention].Â  This contention is incorrect.Â  Domestic law enforcementâ€™s obligation to notify Zimbabweâ€™s foreign consulate does not come under the Vienna Convention, but rather, falls under Article 16 of a bilateral consular convention between the United States and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [no long-title in original], U.S.-U.K., June 6, 1951, 3 U.S.T. 3426, T.I.A.S. No. 2494 [hereinafter U.K. Convention].Â  See also U.S. Department of State, Information for Americans abroad, Consular Notification and Access, Part5:Â  Legal Material, http://travel.state.gov/law/consular /consular_ 744.html.
[8] Art. 36(1)(b), 21 U.S.T. at 101.Â  
[9] Article 16 of the U.K. Convention reads in relevant part:


  (1) A consular officer shall be informed immediately by the appropriate authorities of the territory when any national of the sending state is confined in prison awaiting trial or is otherwise detained in custody within his district. A consular officer shall be permitted to visit without delay, to converse privately with and to arrange legal representation for, any national of the sending state who is so confined or detained. . . .

Art. 16(1), 3 U.S.T. 3426.

Article 36 of the Vienna Convention reads in relevant part:
(b) if he so requests, the competent authorities of the receiving State shall, without delay, inform the consular post of the sending State if, within its consular district, a national of that State is arrested or committed to prison or to custody pending trial or is detained in any other manner. . . . The said authorities shall inform the person concerned without delay of his rights under this sub-paragraph; . . . .

Art. 36(1)(b), 21 U.S.T. at 101.Â  
[10] The U.K. Convention does not have a provision analogous to Article 36(2) of the Vienna Convention which specifically leaves implementation of rights in the Vienna Convention to state law.Â  At the same time, it has no provisions that suggest it should be implemented otherwise.Â  See 21 U.S.T. 3426.
[11] Interestingly, the Sanchez-Llamas opinion made a brief mention of other ways to vindicate a defendantâ€™s Vienna Convention rights, including raising an Article 36 claim â€œas part of a broader challenge to the voluntariness of his statements to police.â€Â 
Id. at 2682.Â Â  We interpret this suggestion as indicating that a defendant may successfully move for a Jackson v. Denno hearing to suppress a statement by asserting a violation of the consular notification provisions of a treaty, along with other factors indicating the involuntariness of a statement (such as the failure to receive Miranda rights).Â Â

title: Colleton County Taxpayers Association v. School District of Colleton County
description: This original jurisdiction case involves a contractual arrangement entered into by the School District of Colleton County and whether this arrangement is illegal in light of the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s limits on the amount of debt a public school district may incur.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Colleton County Taxpayers Association, Edisto Beach Property Owners Association, Inc., South Carolina Public Interest Foundation, David Cannon, Joseph Mire, Marion
Rizer, and Randy White, individually, and on behalf of all others similarly situated,
Plaintiffs,
v.
The School District of Colleton County, Superintendent Charles W. Gale, Jr., SCAGO Educational Facilities Corporation for Colleton School District, Miles Crosby, Rachel Farris, Redell Fields, P. A.
Pournelle, III, and Wayne Shider, Defendants.
      
    
  


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No.Â  26240
Heard October 31, 2006 - Filed December 11, 2006 

DECLARATORY JUDGMENT ISSUED


  
    
      
James G. Carpenter, of the Carpenter Law Firm, of Greenville, for Plaintiffs.
Francenia B. Heizer, Robert L. Widener, and Paul D. Harrill, all of McNair Law Firm, of Columbia, for Defendants.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This original jurisdiction case involves a contractual arrangement entered into by the School District of Colleton County (â€œthe School Districtâ€) and whether this arrangement is illegal in light of the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s limits on the amount of debt a public school district may incur.Â  We hold that the arrangement complies with the relevant constitutional provisions and statutes.
Factual/Procedural Background
In September 2006, the School District adopted a complicated resolution designed to renovate its existing public school facilities and acquire new public school facilities.[1]Â  In its simplest terms, this resolution is an agreement between the School District and the South Carolina Association of Governmental Organizations (â€œSCAGOâ€).
Under the resolution, SCAGO is obligated to create a non-profit corporation (â€œthe Corporationâ€) which will fund the renovation and construction of the countyâ€™s public schools.Â  The resolution requires the School District to convey the existing school facilities to the Corporation and to lease the land on which these facilities sit to the Corporation.[2]Â  The Corporation will then issue corporate revenue bonds to fund the renovation of the existing facilities and the construction of new school facilities, and will also appoint the School District as the Corporationâ€™s agent to oversee the renovation and construction.Â  The resolution further provides that the School District may purchase the renovated or newly constructed facilities by making annual installment payments to the Corporation.[3]
In August 2006, several Colleton County citizens and taxpayer organizations (â€œPlaintiffsâ€) sued the School District and the other Defendants (collectively â€œDefendantsâ€) in the circuit court for Colleton County.Â  This suit requested that the court declare that the resolution and its attendant agreements contained numerous violations of the South Carolina Consolidated Procurement Code, see S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 11-35-10 to -5270 (Supp. 2005), and that the scheme constituted a â€œfinancing agreementâ€ which would impact the amount of the School Districtâ€™s outstanding general obligation debt.[4]Â  The Plaintiffs contemporaneously requested a temporary restraining order to stop the School District from issuing general obligation bonds to raise cash for its first installment payment.Â  The circuit court heard this motion the same day the Plaintiffs filed the complaint and denied the request the following day.
At the Defendantsâ€™ request, this Court removed this case from the circuit court and agreed to hear the matter in the Courtâ€™s original jurisdiction.Â  Following the grant of original jurisdiction, this Court accepted additional pleadings regarding summary judgment as well as an amended complaint and a supplemental answer.Â  Accordingly, all issues before the Court involve competing requests for declaratory judgments raised either by the unresolved motion for summary judgment or the amended complaint and answer.[5]
The parties present the following issues for review:

  
    
      I. 
       Do the resolution and its attendant agreements constitute a â€œfinancing agreement,â€ and if so, has the School District exceeded its allowable amount of outstanding general obligation debt?
        
    
    
      II. 
       Do the resolution and its attendant agreements violate the terms of two prior referenda?
        
    
    
      III. 
       Is the Corporation the agent or alter-ego of the School District and thus subject to the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s outstanding general obligation debt limit?
        
    
    
      IV.  
       Do the resolution and its attendant agreements violate the School Districtâ€™s procurement code and is the School Districtâ€™s â€œprofessional services exceptionâ€ to its procurement code valid?
        
    
    
      V. 
       Did the School District have a â€œvalid public purposeâ€ for its September issuance of general obligation bonds?[6]
    
  

Law/Analysis
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.â€Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  This case primarily involves the interpretation of statutes, which are questions of law.Â 
Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 67, 459 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1995).
I. Financing Agreement/Constitutional Debt Limit
The Plaintiffs argue that the resolution and its attendant agreements constitute a â€œfinancing agreementâ€ and that the School District has exceeded its allowable amount of outstanding general obligation debt.Â  We disagree.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-27-110 (B) (Supp. 2005) provides that unless a governmental entity obtains voter approval, the entity may not enter into a â€œfinancing agreementâ€ if the sum of the â€œprincipal balanceâ€ of the financing agreement and the amount of the entityâ€™s outstanding bonded debt at the time of execution exceeds eight percent of the assessed value of taxable property in the entityâ€™s jurisdiction.[7]Â  The Code defines a â€œfinancing agreementâ€ in section 11-27-110 (A)(6), and it is undisputed that the agreement at issue in this case does not qualify as a financing agreement under the version of the statute reproduced in the 2005 Code Supplement.[8]
Act No. 388 of 2006, however, substantially revised Â§ 11-27-110 (A)(6), and it is these revisions that have led to the current dispute.Â  Under revised Â§ 11-27-110 (A)(6), a financing agreement includes:

any [contract] entered into after August 31, 2006, pursuant to which installment payments of the purchase price are to be paid by a school district or other political subdivision to a non-profit corporation, political subdivision, or any other entity, from any source other than the issuance of general obligation indebtedness by the school district, in order to finance the acquisition, construction, renovation, or repair of school buildings or other school facilities.

Part V, Section 4, Act No. 388, 2006 S.C. Acts Â  3133, 3166-68 (emphasis added).Â  The Plaintiffs allege the resolution and its attendant agreements meet this definition.[9]
As the statute instructs, the application of the revised definition of a â€œfinancing agreementâ€ in this case turns on the source of the funds that the School District will use to make installment payments to the Corporation.Â  The Plaintiffs argue that although the School District manifests an intention to use constitutionally permissible amounts of general obligation debt to raise funds for the installment payments, the agreements use permissive terms that do not restrict the School District to using only general obligation debt.Â  To counter, the School District argues that it intends to make installment payments using only funds derived from the issuance of general obligation debt, and that the permissive terms are used exclusively to protect the School Districtâ€™s rights (1) to opt out of making the payments at any time (an event generally referred to as â€œnon-appropriationâ€) and (2) to use other funds that may be appropriated by another entity for this purpose in the future.
A close examination of the scheme here at issue reveals no violations of the relevant constitutional or statutory provisions.Â  The resolution and its attendant agreements specifically provide that the School District is not obligated to make any payments to the Corporation unless the School District appropriates funds for that purpose.Â  Furthermore, unless and until the School District appropriates funds for an installment payment from a source other than the issuance of general obligation indebtedness, this claim is speculative and thus not ripe for judicial review.Â  See Waters v. South Carolina Land Res. Conservation Commâ€™n , 321 S.C. 219, 227, 467 S.E.2d 913, 917-18 (1996) (stating that an issue that is contingent, hypothetical, or abstract is not ripe for judicial review).
The crux of the Plaintiffs claim goes to the fund raising/repayment scheme on which they allege the School District plans to embark.Â  To make installment payments to the Corporation, the Plaintiffs allege that the School District plans to use revenues to retire a portion of its outstanding general obligation debt, and then issue new general obligation bonds to raise proceeds for the installment payments.Â  The Plaintiffs assert that this bond retirement/re-issuance scheme will occur on an annual basis, and that this process violates Â§ 11-27-110(A)(6)â€™s requirement that, to avoid classification as a â€œfinancing agreement,â€ the installment payments must come from â€œthe issuance of general obligation indebtedness.â€
While not entirely unpersuasive, this argument overlooks the inescapable fact that the scheme put in place by the resolution and its attendant agreements complies with the letter of the statuteâ€™s requirements.Â  Undoubtedly, a school district possesses the authority and ability to use revenue to retire a portion of its general obligation debt.Â  Furthermore, the law clearly supports the proposition that a school district may incur general obligation debt provided the school district remains within the constitutional and statutory limits.Â  We are aware of no authority permitting this Court to regulate a school districtâ€™s activities of this type absent a violation of a constitutional or statutory limitation.
Our jurisprudence in a similar area supports this conclusion.Â  On several prior occasions, numerous South Carolina school systems have struggled with how to finance their infrastructural growth while remaining within the boundaries of their constitutional and statutory general obligation debt limitations.Â  At one time, alternative financing arrangements known as â€œlease-purchaseâ€ agreements were a popular means by which school districts sought to achieve these goals.Â  Under these agreements, a school district would typically lease its land and buildings to a non-profit corporation for a long period of time.Â  After execution of the lease, the corporation would privately raise funds to finance the school renovation and construction, and the corporation would lease the new and renovated facilities back to the school district until the school district had repaid the principal and interest necessary to fund the construction.Â  
As occurred in the instant case, taxpayers challenged these arrangements as violating the relevant limits on a school districtâ€™s general obligation indebtedness.Â  In both Redmond v. Lexington County Sch. Dist. No. Four, 314 S.C. 431, 445 S.E.2d 441 (1994), and Caddell v. Lexington County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 296 S.C. 397, 373 S.E.2d 598 (1988), this Court held that lease-purchase arrangements did not constitute general obligation debt as defined under Article X, Â§ 15 of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  Caddell represents this Courtâ€™s first pronouncement on the subject, and in that case, the Court began by examining the Constitutionâ€™s definition of general obligation debt.Â  296 S.C. at 399-400, 373 S.E.2d at 599.Â  Noting that this definition included only debt that is â€œsecured . . . by a pledge of [the school districtâ€™s] full faith, credit and taxing power,â€ this Court held that the lease-purchase agreements did not implicate the school districtâ€™s constitutional debt limit.Â  Id . at 400, 373 S.E.2d at 599.Â  The Court stated:

In its historical context, general obligation debt refers to that which is â€œultimately secured by taxes on the property within the political entity.â€Â  Thus, general obligation debt embraces neither yearly expenses payable from current revenues nor contingent liabilities of the governmental entity.Â  This is so because the governmental entity is not obligated to impose property taxes for their payment.
***
Similarly, a leaseback arrangement containing an explicit non-appropriation clause places no such requirement on the political entity. . . . Liability under the leaseback arrangement is, at most contingent:Â  The District has the option of terminating simply by refusing to appropriate money for rent.

Id. (footnotes omitted).
Although the instant case involves an â€œinstallment-purchaseâ€ agreement and not a â€œlease-purchaseâ€ agreement, we believe that much of Caddellâ€™s reasoning nonetheless applies.Â  As we stated in Caddell, and reiterated in Redmond:

The premise of the plaintiffsâ€™ argument that the plan for financing and construction . . . is a fraud or works an injustice upon the cityâ€™s taxpayers is that it is a device to accomplish, by change of form with no change of substance, the same result which has been rejected by the voters. This premise is faulty. It is not the construction . . . for which voter approval is required . . . . Rather, it
is the creation of a general obligation debt . . . which requires the assent of the voters. The plan submitted to and rejected by the voters would have created such a general obligation debt. The plan now proposed does not. This difference is constitutionally significant. 

Redmond, 314 S.C. at 434, 445 S.E.2d at 443; Caddell, 296 S.C. at 401-02, 373 S.E.2d at 600 (quoting Guide v. City of Lakewood, 636 P.2d 691, 697 (Colo. 1981) (internal citations and internal emphasis omitted)).
Although it presented the identical issue dealt with in Caddell, Redmond is particularly informative because it added the element of an expression of legislative dissatisfaction with school districtsâ€™ use of lease-purchase arrangements.Â  Specifically, at the time this Court rendered its decision in Redmond, legislation requiring that the amount expended in a lease-purchase agreement be counted towards a school districtâ€™s general obligation debt limit had passed the South Carolina Senate and was under consideration in the South Carolina House of Representatives.Â  See Redmond, 314 S.C. at 434-35, 445 S.E.2d at 443.Â  This Court stated, â€œ[i]f this bill is eventually passed . . . the Defandantâ€™s position will obviously not merit the same result reached in Caddell and in this case.Â  Until the legislature has definitively spoken on this issue, however, we must apply the law as it currently exists.â€Â  Id.
Turning to the instant case, revised Â§ 11-27-110(A)(6), particularly the definition in effect after this coming December 31, clearly represents a legislative pronouncement of the type discussed in Redmond.Â  Unlike Redmond, this case involves legislation which has been passed by the Legislature, signed by the Governor, and is now effective. Â However, as in Redmond, the instant case involves a scheme which complies with the letter of the statutes currently in effect.Â  
The portion of Â§ 11-27-110(A)(6) currently in effect requires only that the school district use funds derived from the issuance of general obligation debt to make payments under an installment-purchase agreement.Â  So long as the School District abides by this requirement, they have not violated the statuteâ€™s requirements.Â  
Accordingly, we deny the Plaintiffsâ€™ request for a declaratory judgment that the resolution and its attendant agreements are â€œfinancing agreementsâ€ which implicate the School Districtâ€™s constitutional and statutory debt limits. Â Additionally, and in accordance with the Defendantsâ€™ request, we hereby issue a declaratory judgment that the resolution and its attendant agreements are in compliance with the relevant constitutional and statutory provisions and limitations.
II. Violations of Prior Referenda
The Plaintiffs argue that the resolution and its attendant agreements violate the results of two prior referenda which denied the School District the right to exceed its general obligation debt limit.Â  We disagree.
In 1998, the citizens of Colleton County rejected a referendum which would have allowed the School District to issue approximately $42 million in general obligation bonds; well in excess of the School Districtâ€™s general obligation debt limit. Â Similarly, in 1999, voters rejected a resolution which would have allowed the School District to issue approximately $39.5 million in general obligation bonds.Â  The Plaintiffs claim that a decision of the School District which results in an increase of the School Districtâ€™s general obligation debt beyond its debt limit violates the results of these referenda.
We hold that this claim does not state a cause of action.Â  The relevant question is whether the School District has violated the constitutional or statutory limits on the amount of outstanding general obligation debt it may incur.Â  The Plaintiffs provide no authority supporting the proposition that a referendum which is wholly rejected (and therefore a nullity) can form the basis of a legal claim.Â  
Accordingly, we grant the Defendantsâ€™ motion for summary judgment as to this claim on the grounds that it fails to state a cause of action.
III. Alter-Ego/Agency
The Plaintiffs argue that the Corporation is the alter-ego of the School District. Â Accordingly, the Plaintiffs argue that the Corporation is subject to the general obligation debt limit the South Carolina Constitution imposes on a school district.Â  We disagree.
An alter-ego theory requires a showing of total domination and control of one entity by another and inequitable consequences caused thereby.Â  Peoples Fed. Sav. & Loan Assoc. v. Myrtle Beach Golf & Yacht Club, 310 S.C. 132, 148, 425 S.E.2d 764, 774 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Control may be shown where the subservient entity manifests no separate interest of its own and functions solely to achieve the goals of the dominant entity.Â  Id.Â  However, this theory does not apply in the absence of fraud or misuse of control by the dominant entity which results in some injustice.Â  Id; see also Baker v. Equitable Leasing Corp., 275 S.C. 359, 367-68, 271 S.E.2d 596, 600 (1980) (holding that control, in and of itself, is not sufficient.Â  It is necessary to show that the retention of separate corporate personalities would promote fraud, wrong or injustice, or would contravene public
policy).
A grant of summary judgment is proper when â€œthere is no genuine issue as to any material fact and . . . the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  Furthermore, when a motion for summary judgment is made and properly supported, an adverse party may not rest solely upon the allegations or denials in his pleading, but must set forth specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for trial.Â  Rule 56(e), SCRCP.
To support their alter-ego cause of action, the Plaintiffsâ€™ amended complaint alleged that the School District or its agents would create the Corporation and select the Corporationâ€™s directors, and also that the Corporation would have â€œno purpose other than to do the will of the School District.â€Â  In their motion for summary judgment, the Defendants relied in large part on the affidavit of the chairman of SCAGOâ€™s board of directors which directly refuted the Plaintiffsâ€™ allegations.Â  Specifically, this affidavit established that SCAGO, not the School District, would form the Corporation, appoint the board of directors, approve the Corporationâ€™s by-laws, and oversee the Corporationâ€™s functions.Â  The affidavit further established that SCAGO is a South Carolina non-profit corporation that was formed in 2002 and that the School District does not have control over SCAGO, nor does it have financial ties to SCAGO.
As the evidence illustrates, the affidavit offered by the Defendants in support of their motion for summary judgment directly refutes the allegations raised in the Plaintiffsâ€™ alter-ego claim.Â  The Plaintiffs have not contested the substance of this affidavit, nor have they set forth any specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for trial on this claim.Â  Accordingly, there is no impediment to our deciding this claim on summary judgment.
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the Plaintiffs, there is simply no support for the conclusion that the Corporation is the alter-ego of the School District.Â  Our alter-ego jurisprudence instructs that the issues of domination and control over one entity by another are two touchstones of the relevant analysis.Â  In the instant case, there is no evidence suggesting the existence of either of these conditions.Â  
For this reason, we grant the Defendantsâ€™ motion for summary judgment and hold that the Corporation is not the alter-ego of the School District.
In addition to an alter-ago claim, the Plaintiffs allege that the Corporation will be acting as the agent of the School District.Â  Accordingly, the Plaintiffsâ€™ contend that the Corporation is bound by the School Districtâ€™s general obligation debt limit because an agent may possess no more authority than the principal.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn agent is one appointed by a principal as his representative and to whom the principal confides the management of some business to be transacted in the principalâ€™s name, or on his account, and who brings about or effects legal relationships between the principal and third parties.â€Â Â  Thompson v. Ford Motor Co., 200 S.C. 393, 414, 21 S.E.2d 34, 43 (1942) (quoting South Carolina v. W.T. Rawleigh Co., 172 S.C. 415, 174 S.E.2d 385 (1934)).Â  Whether one person or entity is the agent of another is determined by examining whether the party alleged to be the principal has the right to control the conduct of the alleged agent.Â  Newell v. Trident Med. Cent., 359 S.C. 4, 12, 597 S.E.2d 776, 780 (2004).
In the instant case, the record contains no evidence indicating that the Corporation will be acting as the School Districtâ€™s agent in any capacity.Â  As we have previously indicated, the evidence illustrates that SCAGO, not the School District, will form the Corporation, appoint the board of directors, approve the Corporationâ€™s by-laws, and oversee the Corporationâ€™s functions.Â  Although the Corporation will raise money to fund the renovation of the School Districtâ€™s facilities, the Plaintiffs cite no authority supporting the proposition that this, in and of itself, creates an agency relationship.Â  Similarly, the record does not contain any evidence indicating that the School District will have any right to control the Corporationâ€™s activities.
Although the Plaintiffsâ€™ argument may accurately summarize the law regarding whether an agent may legally perform acts which, if done by the principal, would be illegal, the Plaintiffs do not present any evidence which tends to establish that the Corporation will serve as the School Districtâ€™s agent in any fashion.Â  Absent such a showing, this axiom of agency law has no framework in which to apply.
Accordingly, we grant the Defendantsâ€™ motion for summary judgment and hold that the Corporation is not the agent of the School District.Â  
IV. Violations of District Procurement Code
The Plaintiffs allege that the resolution and its attendant agreements violate the School Districtâ€™s procurement code because (A) the agreements create contracts with financial advisors, bond attorneys, a bond insurance company, and a company acting as a trustee, all without competitive bidding; (B) the agreements create contracts with SCAGO and the Corporation without competitive bidding; and (C) the contracts with SCAGO and the Corporation are improper multi-year contracts.Â  We disagree.
A. Agreements with financial advisors, bond attorneys, a bond insurance company, and a trustee
The School Districtâ€™s procurement code applies to the expenditure of â€œpublic funds irrespective of their source.â€Â  See District Procurement Code Â§ 1-102.Â  Thus, generally speaking, the School Districtâ€™s procurement code would apply to contracts the School District enters into with financial advisors, bond attorneys, and other similar parties, provided that the contracts require the School District to spend public funds.Â  
In the instant case, however, the resolution and its attendant agreements provide that the Corporation, not the School District, will enter into several of the challenged contracts with financial advisors, bond attorneys, a bond insurance company, and a company acting as a trustee.Â  Unless the School District is a party to these contracts, we can discern no basis upon which to conclude that the School Districtâ€™s procurement code is applicable in these circumstances.Â  Because the record indicates that the School District is not a party to these contracts, it naturally follows that the School Districtâ€™s procurement code, in these events, is inapplicable.Â  
Second, Â§ 2-101 of the School Districtâ€™s procurement code generally provides that all contracts awarded by the School District are to be awarded by competitive sealed bidding.Â  This requirement is not absolute, however, and one exception to this procedure applies to contracts for professional services which are normally obtained on a fee basis.Â  See id. at Â§ 1-103(i) (listing attorneys, accountants, physicians, and dentists as examples of these types of services).
The School District argues that any contracts or agreements it has already formed or will form with bond attorneys or financial advisors will clearly fall under the procurement codeâ€™s â€œprofessional servicesâ€ exception.Â  The Plaintiffs do not dispute this assertion, but instead argue that the School Districtâ€™s â€œprofessional servicesâ€ exception is invalid because the South Carolina General Assembly repealed a similar exception from the South Carolina Consolidated Procurement Code in June 2006.[10]Â  We disagree with the Plaintiffsâ€™ contention.
This argument is unpersuasive.Â  The General Assemblyâ€™s repeal of the Consolidated Procurement Codeâ€™s professional services exception has no relevance to the validity of the School Districtâ€™s identical exception.Â  The Plaintiffs do not argue that Act No. 376 directly repealed the School Districtâ€™s exception, nor do they suggest that the act implicitly repealed the School Districtâ€™s exception.Â  Instead, the Plaintiffs suggest that Act No. 376 amounts to a determination that a professional services exception no longer embodies â€œsound principles of appropriately competitive procurementâ€ within the meaning of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-35-50 (Supp. 2005).
We hold that this conclusory statement is insufficient to present any issue to this Court for review.Â  The Plaintiffsâ€™ brief presents only this blanket conclusion and provides no authority supporting their argument. Thus, the Plaintiffs have effectively waived this argument.Â  See Solomon v. City Realty Co., 262 S.C. 198, 201, 203 S.E.2d 435, 436 (1974) (an exception was deemed effectively abandoned where the argument relating to the exception consisted solely of an inaccurate â€œbald conclusionâ€).
Accordingly, we hold that the School District did not violate its procurement code by entering into contracts with financial advisors or bond attorneys.Â  Furthermore, we hold that the School Districtâ€™s procurement code is irrelevant to contracts the Corporation may enter into with financial advisors, bond attorneys, a bond insurance company, or a company acting as a trustee.
B. Agreements with SCAGO and the Corporation
The Plaintiffs claim that the resolution and its attendant agreements improperly create contracts with SCAGO and the Corporation without complying with the competitive bidding requirement in the School Districtâ€™s procurement code.Â  We disagree. Â 
As our jurisprudence instructs, an issue that is contingent, hypothetical, or abstract is not ripe for judicial review.Â  Waters, 321 S.C. at 227, 467 S.E.2d at 917-18.Â  Stated differently, â€œ[a] justiciable controversy is a real and substantial controversy which is ripe and appropriate for judicial determination, as distinguished from a contingent, hypothetical or abstract dispute.â€Â  Id. (quoting Pee Dee Elec. Co-Op, Inc. v. Carolina Power & Light Co., 279 S.C. 64, 66, 301 S.E.2d 761, 762 (1983)).
The Plaintiffsâ€™ claims on this issue can be grouped into challenges to three arrangements: (1) the arrangement under which the School District is to convey the existing school facilities to the Corporation and lease the land on which these facilities sit to the Corporation; (2) the arrangement under which the School District may purchase the renovated or newly constructed facilities by making annual installment payments to the Corporation; and (3) the construction contracts the School District may enter on behalf of the Corporation.[11]
As a first matter, neither conveying the existing facilities nor leasing the Corporation the land on which these facilities sit involves the expenditure of public funds. Â Therefore, the procurement code does not apply to these agreements.Â  
Second, an adjudication of the Plaintiffsâ€™ claims on the remaining agreements at the present time presumes too much.Â  As yet, no public funds have been appropriated as installment payments under the â€œInstallment Purchase and Use Agreement.â€Â  Thus, this challenge can only be deemed an academic and premature exercise. Â Furthermore, the Plaintiffsâ€™ remaining claim assumes that the School District will award the renovation and construction contracts in a manner other than by competitive sealed bidding.Â  Because this claim involves pure hypothesis and speculation, this claim is not ripe for judicial review.Â  Assuming the Plaintiffs meet the required elements of standing, the proper time to bring this claim would be after the School District awarded a construction contract to a contractor without using the sealed competitive bid process. [12]  
Accordingly, we dismiss the Plaintiffsâ€™ claims that the agreements improperly create contracts with SCAGO and the Corporation without competitive bidding.Â  Most of these claims fail on their merits, and those remaining are not ripe for review.
C. Multi-year Contracts
The Plaintiffs argue that the â€œInstallment Purchase and Use Agreementâ€ (providing for the buy-back of renovated or newly constructed school facilities) and the â€œBase Lease and Conveyance Agreementâ€ (leasing the land on which the renovated school facilities currently sit to the Corporation) violate the procurement codeâ€™s limit on the term of contracts.Â  We disagree.
Section 2-302 of the School Districtâ€™s procurement code generally provides that the School District may not enter into a contract for â€œsuppliesâ€ or â€œservicesâ€ which contains a term agreement extending beyond five years.Â  The procurement codeâ€™s definitional section defines â€œserviceâ€ as â€œthe furnishing of labor, time, or effort.â€Â  See id. Â§ 1-201(22).Â  The section defines â€œsuppliesâ€ as â€œ[a]ll property including . . . leases of real property, excluding land or a permanent interest in land.â€Â  Id.Â  
Because the procurement codeâ€™s plain terms clearly exclude â€œland or a permanent interest in landâ€ from the definitional provisions which are subject to the codeâ€™s limitations on the terms of contracts, concluding that the â€œBase Lease and Conveyance Agreementâ€ is excluded from the procurement codeâ€™s time limit is a rather elementary determination. 
Turning to the â€œInstallment Purchase and Use Agreement,â€ we hold that this contract is also exempt from the procurement codeâ€™s time limitation, but for a different reason.Â  The agreement expressly provides that it is not an agreement for a multi-year term, but is instead a one-year agreement that may, at the School Districtâ€™s option, be renewed until the School District has completely purchased the renovated and newly constructed school facilities from the Corporation.Â  Because this agreement is not for a multi-year term, the procurement codeâ€™s time limitation on contracts does not apply.
Accordingly, we hold that the School District has not violated the time limit on contracts found in its procurement code.
V. Illegal Bond Offering
The Plaintiffs allege that the School District did not have a â€œvalid public purposeâ€ for its September issuance of general obligation bonds because the School District issued these bonds to raise cash for its first installment payment under the resolution.Â  We disagree.
Our determination that the resolution and its attendant agreements are in conformance with the relevant constitutional and statutory provisions effectively forecloses this claim.Â  Accordingly, we deny the Plaintiffsâ€™ request to issue a declaratory judgment that the School Districtâ€™s September issuance of general obligation bonds was illegal, invalid, or ultra vires.
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we hold that the resolution and its attendant agreements do not constitute â€œfinancing agreementsâ€ as defined by the provisions of Â§ 11-27-110 (A)(6) which are currently in effect. Â We therefore determine that the School District has not exceeded its constitutional and statutory debt limit.Â  We further hold that the School District has committed no violations of its procurement code, and we find in favor of the School District on the remaining causes of action.
 MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] The School District adopted a similar resolution in July 2006.Â  At the relevant September meeting, the Board repealed the previous resolution and enacted the one at issue.Â  
[2] This process is detailed in the document titled â€œBase Lease and Conveyance Agreement.â€
[3]  The resolution and its attendant agreements anticipate that the Corporation will issue approximately $90 million worth of bonds to fund the renovation and construction.Â  The repurchasing process is detailed in the document titled â€œInstallment Purchase and Use Agreement.â€ 
[4] The South Carolina Constitution provides that a public school district may incur general obligation debt only in an amount less than or equal to the value of eight percent of the total assessed property value in that district unless a majority of voters in the school district, by referendum, provide otherwise.Â  S.C. Const. art. X, Â§Â§ 15(5) and (6).Â  This value for the School District is approximately $12 million.Â  The date of the Plaintiffsâ€™ complaint precedes the resolution at issue in this case because the Plaintiffs originally challenged the first resolution enacted by the School District.
[5] The Defendantsâ€™ original and amended answers contain counterclaims for declaratory judgments that the resolution and its attendant agreements do not violate the relevant procurement procedures and that the scheme does not impermissibly impact the amount of the School Districtâ€™s outstanding general obligation debt.Â  
[6] This catalogue of the issues differs slightly from the manner in which the parties organized their briefs.Â  We have listed the issues according to the causes of action presented in the Plaintiffsâ€™ amended complaint.Â  For the sake of convenience, we have grouped the Plaintiffâ€™s fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, and eighth causes of action together under Issue IV, which deals with the School Districtâ€™s procurement code.Â  Similarly, the Plaintiffsâ€™ ninth cause of action, which deals with whether the School District or the Corporation is the entity ultimately responsible for the school renovation and construction, falls under Issues III (alter-ego) and IV (procurement code).Â  
[7] Thus, this statute parallels the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s limit on the amount of bonded debt a school district may carry.
[8] Specifically, this version of the statute provides that a financing agreement means a contract under which a governmental entity (1) acquires the use of an asset, (2) makes payments in more than one fiscal year, (3) divides the payments into principal and interest components, and (4) acquires title to the asset if all scheduled payments are made.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-27-110 (A)(6) (Supp. 2005).Â  The agreements at issue here meet requirements one and two, however, the agreements do not provide for payments to be divided into principal and interest components.Â  
Furthermore, under these agreements, title to the renovated and newly constructed school facilities is not contingent upon the School Districtâ€™s satisfying the entire amount of corporate bonds issued by the Corporation.Â  Instead, the Corporation transfers title to an undivided interest in the facilities to the School District each time a payment is made.Â  
[9] Revised Â§ 11-27-110 (A)(6) provides additional definitions of arrangements that constitute financing agreements.Â  These definitions include:

any contract entered into after December 31, 2006, pursuant to which installment payments of the purchase price are to be paid by a school district or other political subdivision to a non-profit corporation . . . in order to finance the acquisition, construction, renovation, or repair of school buildings or other school facilities.

Id.Â  The School District does not dispute that the resolution and its attendant agreements would meet the definition of a financing agreement if executed after December 31, 2006.
[10] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-35-1270 (Supp. 2005) is substantially similar to the School Districtâ€™s â€œprofessional servicesâ€ exception.Â  The General Assembly repealed this entire section during its 2006 session.Â  See Section 63, Act No. 376, 2006 S.C. Acts 2839, 2894. 
[11] The Plaintiffs also challenge the School Districtâ€™s agreement with SCAGO.Â  However, because neither the resolution nor any attendant agreement provides for the School District to pay SCAGO any money, there seems to be no basis upon which we can conclude that the procurement code would apply to such an agreement.
[12] Furthermore, we think it might be argued that these construction contracts do not involve spending public funds.Â  Of course, the parties have not presented these arguments, presumably because none of these contracts currently exist.

description: This order grants petitioner's motion to reinstate the appeal and denies counsel's motion to be relieved as counsel and to appoint new counsel. Further, the order sets forth the procedure to be used by attorneys in submitting Rule 227(c), SCACR, explanations within ethical bounds.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina

  
    
      
        Franklin Dennison, Petitioner,
        
        
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ORDER

By order dated August 31, 2006, this post-conviction relief (PCR) matter was dismissed due to petitionerâ€™s failure to submit an explanation pursuant to Rule 227(c), SCACR, why the lower courtâ€™s finding was improper.Â  Counsel for petitioner has now filed a petition for reinstatement and a motion to be relieved as counsel and for the appointment of new counsel.
These motions are a result of counselâ€™s concerns regarding the potential ethical dilemma presented by the requirement for an explanation under Rule 227(c) when a good faith argument or explanation does not exist.Â  We understand counselâ€™s concerns, but find, based on Rule 71.1, SCRCP, Rule 227, SCACR, and the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 413, SCACR, that counselâ€™s duties can be fulfilled without violating the Rules of Professional Conduct.
A final decision entered under the PCR Act shall be reviewed according to the procedure specified by Rule 227, SCACR.Â  Rule 71.1(g), SCRCP. Â â€œIf an applicant represented by counsel desires to appeal, counsel shall serve and file a Notice of Appeal as required by Rule 227, SCACR, and shall continue to represent the applicant on appeal unless automatically relieved under Rule 602, SCACR, or allowed to withdraw under Rule 235, SCACR.â€Â  Id. Â If the applicant is indigent, counsel shall assist the applicant in obtaining representation by the Division of Appellate Defense.Â  Id.Â  
 
Unlike review of a conviction, which is by direct appeal and is a constitutional right, review of a decision in a PCR matter is discretionary by way of a writ of certiorari.Â  We find it is appointed counselâ€™s duty in PCR matters to serve and file the notice of appeal.Â  Thereafter, if counsel does not have a good faith explanation to provide pursuant to Rule 227(c), counsel shall provide the Court with a letter stating that as an officer of the Court, counsel is unable set forth any arguable basis for asserting the determination by the PCR judge that the PCR application was successive and barred by the statute of limitations was improper.Â  Counsel shall further advise the petitioner by copy of the letter that the petitioner should notify the Court, no later than twenty (20) days from the date of the letter, of any arguable basis the petitioner may wish to assert that the determination that the PCR application was successive and barred by the limitations was improper.Â  Although, generally, a petitioner would not be allowed in such situations to submit a pro se explanation, see Jones v. State, 348 S.C. 13, 558 S.E.2d 517 (2002)(counsel cannot serve as a mere conduit for pro se documents in an effort to avoid the prohibition against hybrid representation and the displeasure of his client) and Foster v. State, 298 S.C. 306, 379 S.E.2d 907 (1989)(no right to hybrid representation), we will allow a pro se explanation in the situation described above.
In the case at hand, we grant the petition for reinstatement and give petitioner twenty days from the date of this order to submit a pro se explanation pursuant to Rule 227(c).Â  However, we deny the motion to be relieved as counsel and to appoint new counsel.Â  In the event petitionerâ€™s pro se explanation is found to be sufficient to allow the appeal to proceed, counsel will be required to assist petitioner in obtaining representation by the Division of Appellate Defense.
 IT IS SO ORDERED.

  
    
    s/Jean H. Toal                                      C.J.
              
              s/James E. Moore                                   J.
              
              s/John H. Waller, Jr.                                 J.
              
              s/E. C. Burnett, III                                      J.
              
              s/Costa M. Pleicones                              J.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
  

In the Matter of David R. Shumate, Petitioner.

ORDER

The records in the office of the Clerk of the Supreme Court show that on January 7, 1991, Petitioner was admitted and enrolled as a member of the Bar of this State.
By way of a letter addressed to the Clerk of the Supreme Court dated December 5, 2006, Petitioner submitted his resignation from the South Carolina Bar. We accept Petitioner's resignation.
Petitioner shall, within fifteen (15) days of the issuance of this order, deliver to the Clerk of the Supreme Court his certificate to practice law in this State.
In addition, Petitioner shall promptly notify, or cause to be notified, by certified mail, return receipt requested, all clients currently being represented in pending matters in this State, of his resignation.
Petitioner shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of the Supreme Court, within fifteen (15) days of the issuance of this order, showing that he has fully complied with the provisions of this order. The resignation of David R. Shumate shall be effective upon full compliance with this order. His name shall be removed from the roll of attorneys.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina

In the Matter of James Stone Craven, Respondent.

ORDER

  
The Office of Disciplinary Counsel has filed a petition asking this Court to place respondent on interim suspension pursuant to Rule 17(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, and seeking the appointment of an attorney to protect respondent’s clients’ interests pursuant to Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR. 
 IT IS ORDERED that respondent’s license to practice law in this state is suspended until further order of the Court.
 IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that James M. Bagarazzi, Esquire, is hereby appointed to assume responsibility for respondent’s client files, trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain. Mr. Bagarazzi shall take action as required by Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, to protect the interests of respondent’s clients. Mr. Bagarazzi may make disbursements from respondent’s trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain that are necessary to effectuate this appointment.
 This Order, when served on any bank or other financial institution maintaining trust, escrow and/or operating accounts of respondent, shall serve as an injunction to prevent respondent from making withdrawals from the account(s) and shall further serve as notice to the bank or other financial institution that James M. Bagarazzi, Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court.
 Finally, this Order, when served on any office of the United States Postal Service, shall serve as notice that James M. Bagarazzi, Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court and has the authority to receive respondent’s mail and the authority to direct that respondent’s mail be delivered to Mr. Bagarazzi’s office.
 This appointment shall be for a period of no longer than nine months unless request is made to this Court for an extension.
